questions.text: Which of the following Hepatitis viruses is a DNA virus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hepatitis B virus HBV is a DNA virus that Comes under the family Hepadnaviridae

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. HAV is a nonenveloped 27-nm, heat-, acid-, and ether-resistant RNA virus in the Hepatovirus genus of the picornavirus family. Option: C. Hepatitis C is an RNA virus under the Flaviviridae There are seven genotypes. Option: D. HEV is the most common cause of acute hepatitis —positive-sense RNA genome under the family Hepeviridae.

Extraedge:

The most common in India is genotype 3 The most common worldwide is genotype1

questions.text: A patient suspected of viral hepatitis undergoes investigations. Which provides a convenient, readily detectable, qualitative marker of HBV replication and relative infectivity?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HBeAg Marker of Infectivity and replication. The qualitative marker of HBV replication and relative infectivity. The presence of HBeAg during chronic hepatitis B tends to be associated with ongoing viral replication, infectivity, and inflammatory liver injury (except during the early decades after perinatally acquired HBV infection)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. HbsAg is the first marker to rise even before the onset of prodromal symptoms. Option: C. HBcAg does not circulate. Option: D. The clinical relevance of HBxAg is limited, however, and testing for it is not part of routine clinical practice

questions.text: What is the role of hepatitis B X antigen (HBxAg) in Hepatitis B?

options.label: A
options.text: Stimulation of HBV reverse transcription and HBV DNA replication

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibition of HBV reverse transcription and HBV DNA replication

options.label: C
options.text: Directs replication and repair of HBV DNA

questions.correct_answer: A. Stimulation of HBV reverse transcription and HBV DNA replication
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Stimulation of HBV reverse transcription and HBV DNA replication The fourth gene, X, codes for a small, nonparticulate protein, hepatitis B x antigen (HBsAg), capable of transactivating both viral and cellular gene transcription . In the cytoplasm, HBxAg affects calcium release (possibly from mitochondria), activating signal-transduction pathways that stimulate HBV reverse transcription and HBV DNA replication.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C. HBcAg is the protein product; it has no signal peptide and is not secreted, but it assembles into nucleocapsid particles, which bind to and incorporate RNA, and which, ultimately, contain HBV DNA . Also packaged within the nucleocapsid core is a DNA polymerase that directs the replication and repair of HBV DNA. Option: D. Stimulates calcium release, NOT inhibits.

questions.text: Hepatitis B is a vaccine-preventable liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV). Hepatitis B is spread when blood, semen, or other body fluids from a person infected with the virus enters the body of someone who is not infected. Which of the following is true about hepatitis B serological markers?

options.label: A
options.text: HBcAg and anti-HBc are not detectable routinely in the serum of patients

options.label: B
options.text: HBcAg is not detectable routinely in the serum of patients, but anti-HBc is readily demonstrable in serum

options.label: C
options.text: Anti-HBc is not detectable routinely in the serum of patients, but HBcAg is readily demonstrable in serum

options.label: D
options.text: HBcAg and anti-HBc are readily demonstrable in the serum of patients

questions.correct_answer: B. HBcAg is not detectable routinely in the serum of patients, but anti-HBc is readily demonstrable in serum
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HBcAg is not detectable routinely in the serum of patients, but anti-HBc is readily demonstrable in serum Hepatitis B core antigen is not detected; only core antibody is detected. Because HBcAg is intracellular and, when in the serum, sequestered within an HBsAg coat, naked core particles do not circulate in serum. Therefore, HBcAg is not detectable routinely in the serum of patients with HBV infection. By contrast, anti-HBc is readily demonstrable in serum, beginning within the first 1–2 weeks after the appearance of HBsAg and preceding detectable levels of anti-HBs by weeks to months.

Highyeild:

Acute infection–Anti HBc IgM(used to differentiate acute versus chronic illness) IgG anti-HBc and Anti HbS—-Recovered. IgG anti-HBc and HBsAg—--chronic infection IgG anti-HBc alone—-Previous infection or Occult infection

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Anti-HBc is readily demonstrable . Option: C. HBcAg is not detectable routinely in the serum of patients, but anti-HBc is readily demonstrable in serum. Option: D. HBcAg is not detectable routinely.

questions.text: A 31-year male recovers from Hepatitis B. Which of the following offers immunity against reinfection with HBV?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti-HBs The temporal association between the appearance of anti-HBs and resolution of HBV infection as well as the observation that persons with anti-HBs in serum are protected against reinfection with HBV, suggests that anti-HBs are the protective antibody .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, C, D: Not reported to offer immunity against reinfection.

questions.text: A 32-year female is diagnosed with Hepatitis B infection. Which of the following can be evaluated as a quantitative marker of its replicative phase?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HBV DNA HBeAg is a qualitative marker, and HBV DNA is a quantitative marker of this replicative phase, during which all three forms of HBV circulate, including intact virions. Over time, the relatively replicative stage of chronic HBV infection gives way to a relatively nonreplicative degree.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: Qualitative marker . Option: B: HBcAg is not detectable routinely in the serum of patients, but anti-HBc is readily demonstrable in serum. Option: D: HBcAg is not detectable routinely.

questions.text: The important category of HBV mutants consists of escape mutants; what occurs in them?

options.label: A
options.text: Single amino acid substitution from arginine to glycine that results in a gain of neutralizing activity by anti-HBs

options.label: B
options.text: Single amino acid substitution from glycine to arginine that results in a gain of neutralizing activity by anti-HBs

options.label: C
options.text: Single amino acid substitution from arginine to glycine that results in a loss of neutralizing activity by anti-HBs

options.label: D
options.text: Single amino acid substitution from glycine to arginine that results in a loss of neutralizing activity by anti-HBs

questions.correct_answer: D. Single amino acid substitution from glycine to arginine that results in a loss of neutralizing activity by anti-HBs
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Single amino acid substitution from glycine to arginine that results in a loss of neutralizing activity by anti-HBs The second important category of HBV mutants consists of escape mutants, in which a single amino acid substitution, from glycine to arginine, occurs at position 145 of the immunodominant alpha determinant common to all HBsAg subtypes. This HBsAg alteration leads to a critical conformational change that results in a loss of neutralizing activity by anti-HBs.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A & C. Single amino acid substitution, from glycine to arginine, occurs. Option: B. Loss of neutralizing activity by anti-HBs.

questions.text: Although the virus does not appear to be associated with tissue injury in any of these extrahepatic sites, its presence in these "remote" reservoirs has been invoked to explain the recurrence of HBV infection after orthotopic liver transplantation. Hepatitis B antigens and HBV DNA have been identified in all extrahepatic sites EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lungs They were not reported in LUNGS. Hepatitis B antigens and HBV DNA have been identified in extrahepatic sites, including the lymph nodes, bone marrow, circulating lymphocytes, spleen, and pancreas. This explains the recurrence of HBV infection after Orthotopic liver transplantation.

questions.text: Under ordinary circumstances, the acute liver injury associated with viral hepatitis can be determined by which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Hepatitis viruses are directly cytopathic to hepatocytes but not the immunologic responses of the host

options.label: B
options.text: The immunologic responses of the host but the hepatitis viruses are not known to be directly cytopathic to hepatocytes

options.label: C
options.text: Both hepatitis viruses are directly cytopathic to hepatocytes and the immunologic responses of the host

questions.correct_answer: B. The immunologic responses of the host but the hepatitis viruses are not known to be directly cytopathic to hepatocytes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The immunologic responses of the host but the hepatitis viruses are not known to be directly cytopathic to hepatocytes Under ordinary circumstances, none of the hepatitis viruses is known to be directly cytopathic to hepatocytes. Evidence suggests that the clinical manifestations and outcomes after acute liver injury associated with viral hepatitis are determined by the immunologic responses of the host .

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE regarding bridging hepatic necrosis in hepatitis?

options.label: B
options.text: Large areas of hepatic cell dropout

options.label: D
options.text: Consists of condensed reticulum, inflammatory debris, and degenerating liver cells

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Less severe histologic lesion A more severe histologic lesion, bridging hepatic necrosis , called subacute or confluent necrosis or interface hepatitis , is observed occasionally in acute hepatitis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. “Bridging” between lobules results from large areas of hepatic cell dropout, with the collapse of the reticulin framework. Option: C & D. Characteristically, the bridge consists of condensed reticulum, inflammatory debris, and degenerating liver cells that span adjacent portal areas, a portal to central veins, or a primary vein to the main This lesion had been thought to have prognostic significance; in many of the described initially patients with this lesion, a subacute course terminated in death within several weeks to months, or severe chronic hepatitis and cirrhosis developed; however, the association between bridging necrosis and a poor prognosis in patients with acute hepatitis has not been upheld. But there is a predictive relationship between chronic hepatitis and bridging necrosis.

Extraedge:

The specific feature in the histopathology of Hepatitis B is ground glass Hepatocyte . This is due to the HBsAg particle in the Endoplasmic reticulum. seen in other conditions but specific to Hepatitis B.

questions.text: Which is the most common route of perinatal transmission of hepatitis B from mother to baby?
questions.correct_answer: B. At the time of delivery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

At the time of delivery Epidemiologic evidence suggests that most infections occur approximately at the time of delivery.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Although the precise mode of perinatal transmission is unknown, and ~ 10% of infections may be acquired in utero. Epidemiologic evidence suggests that most infections occur approximately at the time of delivery and are unrelated to breastfeeding (which is not contraindicated in women with hepatitis B). The likelihood of perinatal transmission of HBV correlates with the presence of HBeAg and high-level viral replication.

questions.text: Which of the following represents high-Risk Populations for whom HBV Infection Screening is recommended?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A, B, C: High-Risk Populations for Whom HBV Infection Screening Is Recommended include Blood/plasma/organ/tissue/semen donors.

Extraedge:

TABLE 332-3 High-Risk Populations for Whom HBV Infection Screening Is Recommended Persons born in countries/regions with a high (28%) and intermediate (≥2%) prevalence of HBV infection, including immigrants and adopted children and including persons born in the United States who were not vaccinated as infants and whose parents emigrated from areas of high HBV endemicity Household and sexual contact of persons with hepatitis B Babies born to HBsAg-positive mothers Persons who have used injection drugs Persons with multiple sexual contacts or a history of sexually transmitted disease Men who have sex with men Inmates of correctional facilities Persons with elevated alanine or aspartate aminotransferase levels Blood/plasma/organ/tissue/semen donors Persons with HCV or HIV infection Hemodialysis patients Pregnant women Persons who are the source of blood or body fluids that would be an indication for postexposure prevention (e.g., needlestick, mucosal exposure, sexual assault) Persons who require immunosuppressive or cytotoxic therapy (including anti-tumor necrosis factor treatment for rheumatologic or inflammatory bowel disorders)

questions.text: The serological response of hepatitis B infection is shown below. What does the green curve represent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anti-HBe

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: Yellow curve. Option: B: Blue curve. Option: D: Purple curve.

questions.text: Classification of chronic hepatitis is based on which of the following features?

options.label: C
options.text: Degree of progression based on level of fibrosis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Classification of chronic hepatitis was based primarily on Histopathological features but is replaced by category based on clinical, serologic, and histologic variables. Classification of chronic hepatitis is based on (1 ) its cause; (2) its histologic activity or grade; and (3) its degree of progression based on the level of fibrosis or stage . Thus, neither clinical features nor histologic components—requiring liver biopsy or non-invasive markers of fibrosis—alone are sufficient to characterize and distinguish among the several categories of chronic hepatitis.

questions.text: The liver biopsy of a 25-year-old patient shows most of the lobules with portal fibrosis. What score is based on the most popular histologic activity index (HAI)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B: Few Bridging fibrosis. Option: C: Much bridging fibrosis. Choice: D: Incomplete Histologic Grading and Staging of Chronic Hepatitis. Fibrosis (stage) None Total 0 Portal fibrosis-some 1 Portal fibrosis-most 2 Bridging fibrosis-few 3 Bridging fibrosis-many 4 Incomplete cirrhosis 5 Cirrhosis 6 6

questions.text: A 35-year male is being evaluated for chronic hepatitis. Which of the following is NOT a laboratory feature suggestive of chronic hepatitis B?

options.label: C
options.text: Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) tends to be more elevated

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hyperglobulinemia Hyperglobulinemia and detectable circulating autoantibodies are distinctly absent in chronic hepatitis B (in contrast to autoimmune hepatitis).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, C. As is true for acute viral hepatitis B, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) tends to be more elevated than aspartate aminotransferase (AST); however, once cirrhosis is established, AST tends to exceed ALT. Levels of alkaline phosphatase activity tend to be expected or only marginally elevated. Option: D. In severe cases, moderate elevations in serum bilirubin (51.3-171 μmol/L [3-10 mg/dL]) occur. Hypoalbuminemia and prolongation of the prothrombin time occur in severe or end-stage cases.

questions.text: Treatment is recommended regardless of HBeAg status and ALT as long as HBV DNA is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

More fabulous than 2000 IU/mL For patients with compensated cirrhosis, because antiviral therapy has been shown to retard clinical progression, treatment is recommended regardless of HBeAg status and ALT as long as HBV DNA is detectable at >2 × 10 3 IU/mL (detectable at any level according to the EASL)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Needs evaluation of other factors. Option: C, D. Needs Treatment.

questions.text: Window period in hepatitis B is?

options.label: A
options.text: Disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti HBs

options.label: B
options.text: Disappearance of HBsAg & the appearance of anti-HBC

options.label: C
options.text: Appearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBC

options.label: D
options.text: Appearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti HBs

questions.correct_answer: A. Disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti HBs
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti HBs Hepatitis B may be spread from infected mothers to their babies at birth (' vertical' transmission) . The transmission rate of hepatitis B from mother to newborn is very high , and almost all infected infants will develop chronic hepatitis B. Transmission can be significantly reduced through immunoprophylaxis. This risk is as high as 90% if the mother is also favorable for HBeAg. Symptoms usually begin six weeks to 6 months after exposure to the virus. Hepatitis has an age-dependent prognosis. Children are less likely than adults to clear the infection. More than 95% of people who become infected as adults or older children will stage a full recovery and develop protective immunity to the virus. Window period = Disappearance of HBs antigen & appearance of HBs Ab The first marker to be detected in an infected patient is HBsAg.

questions.text: HBV Replication is indicated by all of the following, Except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

HBsAg Markers for HBV Replication:- Qualitative Markers: - HBe Ag is a qualitative marker for HBV replication Quantitative Markers

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. HBV DNA is a definitive quantitative marker for HBV replication Option: B. DNA polymerase is a definitive marker for HBV replication

Extraedge:

HBsAg is the first marker to be found positive in an infected patient.
